dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A roulette table. The PUNTERS place their bets. TWELVE  PLAYERS, nine men, three women. The FACES of the men, all ages, intense, hopeful, fearful. Which of them is JACK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he had become the still centre  of that spinning wheel of  misfortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN'S hand spins the wheel. The ball is thrown against  the spin. Hands, faces, chips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world turned round him...  leaving him miraculously untouched  The little white ball circles the  spinning wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PUNTERS'S faces as the ball starts to bounce. All eye are on the bouncing ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The croupier had reached his goal.  He no longer heard the sound of  the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back of the CROUPIER'S hand, his slicked-back short  hair, razor cut. The CAMERA moves around to his face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To begin with he was Jack Manfred...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: whistling sound takes Jack back in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is walking through a maze of open-plan partitioned  offices. He ls casually but fashionably dressed, hair dye blond long, a nervous elegance about him, almost  unrecognisable from the croupier's face. He searches for the right office. He finds it. The name o the open is GILES CREMORNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GILES CREMORNE, a public schoolboy in his late twenties  comes forward and vigorously shakes JACK'S hand. Jacketle he wears yellow braces. Next to his tidy desk is a slot  machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a pew, Jack. You look well.  What's it been, two years since we  broke bread?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GILES has an upper-class accent, but an acquired street  manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three years, two months. March  '93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a memory you've got. Maths  always was your strong suit. What  happened to the moaning Lisa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She went back to South Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (digging) Did she? (smiles) You were pretty thick at one time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all played the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GILES frowns at a memory, an implication. GILES'S mobile  phone buzzes. He picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi-ya... I'll call you back. (to Jack) Now then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) I want a job, Giles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautiously) All right. As what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking perhaps I could be  a reader. You employ readers, don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do. For unsolicited manuscripts.  We pay twenty pounds a manuscript.  You might get two, maybe three in  a week. Can you live on sixty  pounds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK opens a pack of Gitanes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. This is a no-smoking office,  Jack. You've written a book, haven't  you? I didn't read it myself, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN SECRETARY puts her head into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me ten minutes, Fiona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIONA puts a fax on GILES'S desk, smiles at JACK, and goe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fiona used to read for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He winks at JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you about our operation.  We like personality authors. People  the public recognises. Celebrity's  what sells books. We can always  find someone to do the writing.  First, we need the face. Then the  concept. (he is reading the  fax) Right now I'm looking for a soccer  novel. Something where a tycoon  buys a lousy team and takes it to  the top. Seven figure transfer  fees. Corruption all down the line.  Violence on and off the pitch.  Steroids. Got any concepts? It  could be a thug story. I tell you  what. Why don't you think about  it. A couple of pages.  The pitch.  Steroids. Got any concepts? It  could be a thug story. I tell you  what. Why don't you think about  it. A couple of pages. (smiles) With plenty of sex, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GILES pops a coin into the slot machine, pulls the handle waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting, Giles. I will think  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machine spits out several coins. GILES takes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me give you three words of  advice, Jack. Don't give up. Stick  with it. Who persists wins. That's  my motto. Write, write, write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK nods, extends his hand. A firm handshake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack had three words for, Giles.  Go fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeting over. GILES smiles goodbye, pockets his slot mach winnings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The untidy evidence. To the accompaniment of the music, a discordant version, three dog-eared copies of 'The Invent Of The Wheel', A Novel by JACK MANFRED. Worn furniture. A pile of literary magazines. Two elegantly arranged vases  of flowers.  Women's fashion magazines. Books everywhere, including 'Scarne on Gambling', 'The Education of A Poker Player', 'Delta of Venus' and other books by Anais Nin. A woman's dress, back from the cleaners. A framed etching o Cape Town, South Africa, in the eighteenth century.  Finally... Beneath the iron barred window, with a view of the iron  steps down from the street, JACK sits at the dining table In front of him is a word processor. He toys with a glass of vodka, smoking a Gitane, and leafing through a soccer  fan magazine. He starts to touch-type, looking at the  screen, not the keyboard. Words appear, letter by letter. THE BALL... A NOVEL... BY JACK MANFRED. He pauses to drin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN, face unseen, steps into a phone booth. CLOSE ON:  his hands.  It is impossible to tell where he is. He opens his pocket book, addresses, diary etc., and  searches through for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds what he's looking for: a small photograph, among others of girls, of a ten year-old boy in school uniform. On the back are three phone numbers, two of them crossed  out. The MAN lifts the receiver, inserts coins. He starts to press the numbers. There are CLOSE-UPS of his finger  pressing the sequence of digits, each one CLOSER, longer  than the one before, until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. JACK looks to the answering machine, wai for the voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacko, if you're there, pick up. I  want to talk to you. It's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK hesitates, then picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAN is handsome, tanned, 50ish, white shirt, dark tie He is JACK'S father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The subsequent conversation is INTERCUT between SITTING  ROOM and PHONE BOOTH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found a job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I've got something for you.  In London, I mean. I've been  chatting to some friends. Do you  know the Golden Lion casino? It's  in Bayswater, I believe... They're  looking for a dealer, a croupier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK SR pulls out a cigarette - a Gitanes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I want to do, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK stubs his cigarette out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting his  cigarette) Don't be stubborn. The pay won't  be grand, but it's regular. That's  what you need, isn't it? I know  you don't like taking my advice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drinks) It's not that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've set this up for you. Call the  Golden Lion and ask for Mr Reynolds,  he's the Manager. I don't know him  personally, but I've spoken to his  boss. Don't say no, Jacko. Give  yourself a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK reaches for a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't. Goodbye, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do it. You've got the knack,  you've got the personality, you  got that from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand the punters. Think  about it, you can write during the  day and sleep knowing the bills  are paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks, he watches passing WOMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake, Jacko, don't  look a gift horse in the mouth.  Have you written that name down?  Reynolds, at the Golden Lion. (exhales)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhales) All right, dad. Yes, I'll call  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is not enthusiastic, but he scribbles the name down  on a pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how are you doing, dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I've just started a new  company. Solid financing. It's  good. (pause) I love you Jacko, you know that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let yourself down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.  Goodbye, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stubbing out his cigarette, JACK SR. leaves the booth. We now see where he is. A beach bar in South Africa. He walk to the bar and....goes behind it, slipping on his barman' jacket. A WOMAN in dark mirror glasses and a bathing suit is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Sorry to keep you. What'll you  have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK, disturbed by the call, pours himself a vodka. He  looks at what he's written: 'THE BALL... A NOVEL BY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack knew something was wrong.  He'd forgotten Giles' advice. Giles  said three words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK inserts a word in the title. It now reads: 'ON THE  BALL'. JACK drinks. After a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK'S VOICE No. Jack knew it still  wasn't quite right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He types: 'IN THE BALLS'. Then, on reflection, deletes 'I THE'.  Through the iron bars JACK watches feet pass on th street above. A drunk drops a beer can over. The can fall in SLOW MOTION but the clatter is loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to fuck the whole world  over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reception area. The CAMERA turns around the fake glitz of the interior: brass, drapes, polished wood, mirrors, and  moves towards the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back Jack... to the house  of addiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Against a blaze of street daylight, JACK' silhouette appears. The CAMERA moves forward to greet him JACK removes his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK shakes hands with DAVID REYNOLDS, a cold man in his  late forties, dead behind the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Reynolds, I'm the Manager  here. Sit down, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS examines a file in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been recommended by the  management here. They know your  father. He has a bit of a  reputation, hasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns) Has he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In any case, I understand you've  had some previous experience... in  South Africa. (Jack nods) You'll find the rules a little  different here. Before we start,  you haven't got a police record,  have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS opens the door. He lets JACK go on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surpised) I was at Beadles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I know that one.   Private, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The full overhead lights give the casino an exposed, tack appearance, devoid of mystery or glamour. The place has  roulette tables and blackjack counters. It is deserted  except for several CLEANING LADIES, vacuuming, emptying  ashtrays. REYNOLDS walks with JACK, talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three types of casino in  the U.K. High volume. Small faction.  And MOTR. That's middle of the  road. Us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a Salon Prive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried. But there wasn't enough  business. The punters like company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS goes to one of the tables with JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see you handle the chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides open a box and tips 200 chips of varying  denominations onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to assume the serial numbers  on the bowl and cylinder correspond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We check every four days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why four? And not three or five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It's the procedure here. Now sort  the chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK starts to stack the chips in piles from a hundred  pounds to five. REYNOLDS watches. JACK'S fingers work fas In a matter of moments he has the lot stacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacks of 20. Rows of 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any exceptions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 pounds or 25 pence in fours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me 365.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses a stopwatch in his hand. JACK quickly sets out four neat piles, three of 100, one of 65. All four piles  are in denominations of ten and five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. Now take these colours...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws a pile of blue and white chips on the table.   The blue are 10, the white are 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want 780, but I want 500 in  denominations of 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK nods and gets to work. His fingers make Reynolds's  ticking watch seem slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now at a roulette table, REYNOLDS has prepared the bets  for fifteen punters. It's a set-up to test Jack's style  and concentration. REYNOLDS gives JACK the white ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You use two alternating, don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do. (hands him a second  ball)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Where's the magnet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been tested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK spins the wheel, throws the ball against the turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the ball begins to bounce, but before it stops, REYNOL turns to a CLEANING LADY who's emptying some ashtrays  nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you stop that for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WOMAN looks up, surprised. JACK watches, then catches sight of REYNOLDS surreptitiously moving a chip onto the  third line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, I've called no  more bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK reaches across, takes the chip and puts it on the  wood Grounding the wheel. REYNOLDS nods approvingly. The  ball stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 Red. Odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He now rakes away the losers' chips and pays out the  smallest first, before getting to the major pay-out on 23 It's all very efficient and speedy. REYNOLDS is increasingly impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you forgotten something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks) I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wipe your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK takes out a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with your own cloth. Besides,  your pockets will be stitched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens if I want to sneeze?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't. Not without permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK laughs. REYNOLDS smiles. They like each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Now let's move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blackjack table. JACK is turning cards over for five  punters in an arc. REYNOLDS is moving from one chair to  the next playing each of the five hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many aces are left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make it six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS looks down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a rule. Always stand by your  first count. The odds are you're  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK pulls out the shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) I said good call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS walks away. JACK puts the shoe back. He takes hi watch out of his pocket, glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It had taken him 45 minutes, but  Jack now had Mr Reynolds's number.  The man couldn't count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the office REYNOLDS is talking to JACK. On  REYNOLDS'S desk is a framed photograph of his suburban  wife and two kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me just run through a few  things. As a dealer you never  gamble, not anywhere. We'll need  your picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the database. It can be accessed  by every casino in the country. We  have the same system for punters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't gamble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't gamble, Mr Reynolds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS doesn't pursue it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next point. Friendships between  croupiers inside or outside the  casino are discouraged.  Relationships with females working  here are expressly forbidden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had the same rule at Sun City,  but it was impossible to check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't South Africa. We'd know,  because someone would report it.  Believe me, someone always does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does know? Or does report? What  would happen if I knew something  like that and didn't report it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd know. There are no secrets in  this casino. You'd be punished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First offence: verbal warning.  Second offence: written warning.   That one's filed and sometimes  copied to the Gaming Board. My  discretion. Third offence: you're  sacked on the spot. You'd never  work in a casino in this country  again.  There's another rule: you're  forbidden to talk to or recognise  a punter outside the casino. If  you see someone who's gambled here,  even if it's just casually on the  street, you must ignore him. Or  her. You're not married, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK shakes his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not in the gaming business  is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CCTV Centre over the casino. JACK crosses the room,  looking down through a glass floor at the empty casino  below. REYNOLDS walks over to a series of twenty or more  banked TV monitors with many Video 8 tape decks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our Crow's Nest. I'm showing  it to you now, but you'll never  see it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have tapes in here that go back  six months. Let me show you  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS presses a button. Together they look at a TV  monitor which shows an overlook of a roulette table where a WOMAN is cheating. REYNOLDS freezes the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that?  That was six weeks ago.  The dealer missed it. The guy up  here missed it, but I watch these  tapes after hours. Nothing gets by  me. Now the lady's in jail. It's  easier to take ten million pounds  from a bank than take one penny  from this casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again in the office. REYNOLDS extends his hand. JACK shak it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can start Monday week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That hair will have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you planning to make a career  in casino work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And end up like you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, you're not the usual type we  get here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Reynolds was right. It was true.  Jack was up above the world. An  artist, living in the clouds.  Looking down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HIGH ANGLED SHOT of the office, JACK and REYNOLDS. The  phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS picks up and listens. The CAMERA descends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't talk about this now... no,  I'm with somebody. They can wait!   I'll be home at the usual time...  all right, I'll call you back in  an hour... (hangs up) Don't ever get married, Jack. Casino  work doesn't mix with house and  garden. Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA reaches a LOW ANGLE on JACK, looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. What's the salary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street lamps have come on. JACK is at the wheel of a  Sixties Austin-Healey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The casino paid its staff monthly  in arrears. He would have to wait  six weeks for his first cheque. He  needed money now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a canopy of coloured lights A CAR DEALER is walking round jack's car, examining it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fake American accent) What kind of deal you looking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the Blue Book price?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not relevant. An old car  like this, it depends on the  condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car was a gift from Jack's  father. That's to say, Jack Senior  had given it to him before the  bailiffs arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DEALER picks at the cracked leather seats, the  protruding stuffing, the chipped dashboard, the rust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't exactly what you'd call  mint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends down and looks underneath the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about fifteen hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about we split the diff...  Seven-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your idea of arithmetic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a mathematician. I'm in  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DEALER looks at JACK. JACK stares back. It's as if on is waiting for the other to blink first. Neither blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly wanted to be rid of  it. 'Hang on tightly, let go  lightly'. It was a saying Jack  remembered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK leans into the open car and takes out his hat and  cigarettes. He has accepted the offer. The music begins..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And continues. JACK stands, with an unlit cigarette,  in a crowded moving train. He looks at the faces, MEN and WOMEN. He sees PEOPLE reading books. He looks at the TITL Romantic fiction, Classics, Business Management, Thriller Self-Help, Cooking....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack imagined people reading his  book. One day he would enter their  heads, play with their imaginations,  test their feelings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK crosses the road. He turns down a side street where  Victorian houses have been converted into flats. There ar scores of 'For Sale' and 'To Let' signs down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would tell them you have to  make a choice in life. Be a gambler  or a croupier. And then live with  your decision come what may.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes down into a basement, closing the iron gate behin him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK unlocks the door, goes in, to the accompaniment of  street sounds and a dog barking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion saw life differently. She  was a romantic. And thought he was  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radio music is playing from another room. An orchestral  version of 'Try a Little Tenderness'. JACK comes in, hang his hat up, looks around. He sees a neatly arranged vase  of flowers that wasn't there before. He goes to the bedro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK sees on the bed, an open box and a carrier bag from designer department store. Among the white tissue paper i a simple black silk dress and lace-decorated black  underwear. He smiles and picks up the knickers. He goes t the open bathroom door, from which comes the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A radio plays beside the bath. The water is draining away MARION NEIL, a red-haired woman in her mid-thirties, wear a bathrobe with the name MARION on it is examining the  lines on her neck in the half-steamed bathroom mirror. Sh sees JACK, turns with a smile. JACK holds up the black  knickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't resist them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean I won't resist them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. I'm not ready for you.  There's some vodka in the freezer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) I won't be that long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes him gently with the flat of her palms towards  the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK comes back into the bedroom. MARION pushes the bathr door, not quite closed. JACK tosses the knickers onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK takes the vodka bottle out of the freezer, pours  himself a glass. He sees two bottles of wine opened, food neatly prepared, ready to cook, an open cook book. He pou a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK sits drinking his vodka. Looking up through the barr window he sees women's legs passing on the street above.  On the desk beside the computer is the glass of wine. MARION materialises in the door to the bedroom. She is  made up, wearing the black dress and high-heeled black  shoes, a black scarf around her neck. JACK takes the glass of wine and gives it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really are a beautiful woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) It's not just inner beauty, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARION whirls to show off her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all I desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for an envelope on the desk. He gives it to  her. MARION opens it. There are several fifty pound notes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I. sold the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have done that. I  know what it meant to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe you for the rent. It's only  a car. I can get another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it back. Till you sell your  book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Marion. Let's face the  truth. Nobody's going to publish  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they will. You just have  to be patient. I'm betting on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She raises the glass of wine, drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not much of a bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drains his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes her scarf, puts it round his neck, pulls him  seductively towards the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come into my world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She winds the black scarf across his face, covering his  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) You're my prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got something to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) What job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARION pulls the scarf from his eyes. She wants to look a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a casino. As a croupier. A  dealer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you land that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It came my way. 450 a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits up) 450? What did you do, just walked  in and said I want to be a croupier?  Don't you need training?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had training. In the Republic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a croupier there? You  never told me that. I thought you  just knew some gamblers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I start Monday week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the street comes the whining sound of a car alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 450 a week. I've never earned that  in my life. You're an enigma, you  are. A fucking enigma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an enigma, just a contradiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARION looks deeply into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sold the car. You got a job.  What's the third thing? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no third thing. Don't be  superstitious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you Jack, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he half-loved Marion. And she  knew that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, the car alarm stops. JACK takes MARION'S head in his hands. She reaches for one of them, examines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to read my palm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got such beautiful hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hands of a conjuror, a woman  had told him once. Or a card sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their hands interlock. She leads him into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK'S hands are being worked on by a woman MANICURIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What line of work are you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an undertaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MANICURIST stops for a moment, looks at him with  curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BARBER is cutting JACK'S hair. He goes up JACK'S neck  with electric clippers. Jack's hair is now black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you work round here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My office is in Shanghai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an arms dealer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BARBER stops for a moment, nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of the mirror JACK buttons a white shirt and  skillfully ties a black bow tie. His short hair is lacque back. He reaches down for his black jacket... puts it on. The transformation is complete. As he scrubs his nails, JACK sees a WOMAN in the mirror.  She is changing her clothes. She pulls off her Indian cot dress. She's wearing pants but no bra. Quite  unselfconsciously, not looking Jack's way, she dresses in her casino clothes. JACK dries his hands. He turns. The WOMAN smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Bella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Manfred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Jack. (fits herself into  the uplift bra) Welcome to the cesspit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it that bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts to do up  her top) How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like trouble, Bella. You look fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The punters love it. Tits in  uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK appears at the head of the table. The PUNTERS look a him, not recognising him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual bunch. They didn't know  Jack, but he knew them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fat INDIAN PUNTER addresses JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the other fellow? Where's  Geoff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't work here any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's hope you know your  job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN trying to look as young as possible  throws 100 pounds in cash to JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tens, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to the WOMAN next to her, who looks very simila

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps this man will bring us  luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WOMAN has sensed her friend's interest in JACK. She's jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack) What's that aftershave you're  wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never converse with the punters.  It slows things down. Speed is  volume, and volume is profit for  the casino. Aim at twenty spins an  hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK pretends he hasn't heard the question. In the  background REYNOLDS is watching as JACK spins the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last bets, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. A plastic-looking BLONDE WOMAN, heavily made-up,  sits at the table. She nods to JACK. PUNTERS are placing  their bets. She has 50 casino chips of 100 denomination in front of her. JACK notes the large sum. The BLONDE puts 2,500 on red and 2,500 on black. PUNT round the table are astonished at the size of the bet and the strangeness of betting both red and black. JACK spins the wheel. Black 10 comes up. JACK takes the  red loss and moves it across the table to the black win.  The BLONDE picks up the 5,000 without a reaction and le the table. JACK notices that she goes straight to the cashier's desk JACK clears the chips away, starts to pay out. A WHITE-HAIRED MAN on JACK's right speaks to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're new here. You'll get used  to Madame Claude. She comes in  once or twice a week and does that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew the scam. Come in with  five grand cash. No questions asked.  Launder it by getting a casino  cheque when you cash in. Jack  wondered why Mr Reynolds permitted  it? After all there's was no profit  in it for the casino. Or was there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. A different set of PUNTERS. The wheel spins. A GRE MAN sits at the table. He doesn't attempt to bet. He look around to see a CROUPIER in his late 20's waiting to repl JACK at the wheel. This is MATT. He gives JACK a curious  complicitous smile. JACK collects the chips and pays out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, ladies and  gentlemen. I'm going to hand you  over now to my colleague. Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATT takes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS appears and takes JACK'S arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Good work, Jack. You handled  yourself well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the table, MATT glances at the GREEK man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is now dealing to FIVE PUNTERS. He has a 10 and a 5  exposed for the house. TWO PLAYERS go bust. ONE PLAYER  sticks on 19, the next on 20. The LAST PLAYER buys a card for 21. JACK turns over an ace for the house. He twists  again. It's a 5 - making 21. The two losing PLAYERS groan The LAST PLAYER is paid evens for equalling the house. On of the PLAYERS who's gone bust gets up, having lost all  his chips, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly a delayed wave of elation  came over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the casino an Oriental man, MR TCHAI, is walking  towards the table with REYNOLDS. Behind him is a 6 foot 5 bulging BODYGUARD. REYNOLDS comes up to JACK's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you take a break, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) All right, Mr Reynolds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves his chair back, nods at the remaining PLAYERS. M TCHAI sits down, watched by the BODYGUARD. BELLA comes up, smiles sweetly, and takes over from JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr Tchai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TCHAI pulls out a sealed bank packet of 5,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy yourself, Mr Tchai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS waves to a WAITRESS who comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mr Tchai) Your usual, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TCHAI nods. He hands her a 50 note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Enjoy your game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 for a diet Coke. Waitresses  were the true winners in the casino.  They were the only members of staff  allowed to accept tips. On a good  night they could get between 200  and 300.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WAITRESS goes. The other PLAYERS at the table look at MR TCHAI, wondering who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS walks with JACK across the casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Tchai always likes to play at  that table, and only with Bella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) He's a good customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good customer is a consistent  loser. Was that what Mr Reynolds  meant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is changing into his street clothes. The young croup MATT comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you live, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got transport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going over the river. I'll  give you a lift if you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATT puts the car into gear, drives off, JACK sitting bes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how do you feel, your first  night? I'll bet you're on a high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's my baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you worked at the  casino?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming up to two years now. (mysteriously) But I was away for six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done pretty well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smugly) Not bad. I have other interests,  of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATT spins the car round a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off to a little watering hole.  Why don't you join me? Relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, Matt. I need my eight  hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll lay you five to one you won't  sleep. In this job you have to  unwind. Otherwise it'll kill you.  I mean that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK pours himself a vodka, smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK starts to take his clothes off. MARION is asleep in  bed. She wakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clock beside the bed reads 4.30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets into bed beside her. She takes him in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shaking. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tension. It'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor baby.  This'll relax you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to massage his neck, his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved it blond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only hair. I haven't changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARION is dressed in a suit, preparing to leave. She thro her nightgown into a laundry basket. JACK is asleep. She  bends to kiss him. He wakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get home, I'm asleep.  When I leave home, you're asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dreamily) I'll see you in my dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARION drops a set of keys into her bag, glances at JACK' covered computer. She draws the curtain back. Daylight  illuminates the old etching of Cape Town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI DE VILLIERS is 30-something, blonde, tanned,  expensively dressed in designer clothes. She gives JACK  ten 50 notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In 20s, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slots the cash into the "bank" beneath the table, then counts out 500 in 20 chips. He slides the chips towar her, looks at her. She smiles. There are ten other PEOPLE at the roulette table. An ARAB LOOKING MAN with a moustache behind JANI is looking down  the front of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns) Place your bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the table the PUNTERS move their chips onto number lines, colours. JANI throws three chips to JACK and calls the numbers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK places them for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack could see this woman was an  experienced gambler. Professionals  always place their bets through  the croupier. That way there are  no comebacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wheel spins, 11 is the number. JACK calls the number  and puts the 'dolly' on 11. JANI smiles faintly. JACK pay out across the table. JANI leaves two chips on 11 The MAN behind JANI puts his chips on 11.  JANI glances up at him She sees the MAN is betting with her. JACK spins the whee again. 33 comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI bets again on number 11. The MAN follows suit. The  wheel spins. JACK watches the table. JANI glances at him. The MAN moves closer to the table to one side of JANI.  Concealed in his hand is a chip. As the ball bounces roun and lands again on number 11, the MAN deftly adds the chi to the square. JACK clocks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, that's a late bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Arabic accent) What are you talking about? It's  11, I've won. With this lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) You've won with the two chips you  placed earlier, but the third chip  was a late bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put them on together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that's not so, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS, who has been watching the tables, sees the  beginning of an incident. He comes over. The MAN is getti angry. JANI watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here, you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a problem, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. This croupier is accusing me  of cheating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a late bet. This gentleman  has been following the lady's  numbers and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAN interrupts JACK and touches JANI's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jani) Do you think I cheated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK and REYNOLDS wait. JACK glances at JANI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my opinion... it was a late  bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should talk about this,  sir. Away from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) No. I won. I want to be paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bangs his fist on the felt. JACK waits for REYNOLDS'S  decision. REYNOLDS looks at JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay the gentleman. In full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS steps back, JACK pays out JANI and the MAN. The  MAN takes his winnings. He looks at JACK with hatred, the leaves the table. REYNOLDS watches him, looks to JACK and nods. JANI collec her winnings and throws two chips to JACK. She stands up  to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, madam, we don't accept  gratuities in the UK. It's different  in South Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) You know where I'm from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK nods and gives her back the two chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lived there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Well, thank you anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK watches her leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright woman, he thought. She knew  the rule of gold. Quit when you're  ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI heads towards the cashier. JACK sees REYNOLDS arguin with the irate ARABIC MAN near the entrance. He looks back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Place your bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his way out the ARABIC MAN looks towards JACK and make an occult sign with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late. There are few PUNTERS left at the tables. JAC tidies up his table, which is next to MATT's. He looks  across at MATT and sees the GREEK MAN who was at the tabl the first night when MATT took over. The GREEK wins on a  number. MATT clears the table and counts out the GREEK'S  winnings, quickly and efficiently. JACK stiffens. He sees that something is wrong. MATT move piles of chips across to the GREEK, who doesn't look up.  JACK glances in the direction of the hidden video cameras and the crows' nest. REYNOLDS is in the back-ground, has  seen nothing untoward. JACK watches the GREEK pick up his winnings and leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again MATT is driving JACK home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Look Matt, there's something I  have to say to you. I saw you  cheating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (violently) What the fuck are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Greek guy who won at the end.  You paid him out in 25s not 20s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) I don't cheat, Jack. You've got it  wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to report it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATT slams on the brakes. The car comes to an abrupt stop MATT turns to JACK, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, a cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I see you do it again, I'll  report it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get you. Even if it was  true, which it isn't, what the  fuck difference would it make to  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if a supervisor knew I'd  seen you and I hadn't reported it,  I'd lose my job as well. And I  can't afford that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's Mr Clean. Wise up, Jack,  this whole business is bent. The  casino is nothing but legal theft.  And that's OK. It's the system.  Half the punters who come in are  using stolen money, drug money,  they haven't earned it. We earn  our money. (softens) I'm on your side, Jack. I don't  need an enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about complicity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what that means. I'm  talking about not rocking the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATT holds out his hand for JACK. JACK shakes it. MATT  grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, now let's unwind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the car into gear and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt was an escape artist. Like  Jack's father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATT's car pulls up in the parking lot at the back of the restaurant.  He and JACK get out of the car and go throug the open kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen is full of people, some involved in cooking,  some standing around smoking and drinking, mostly Greek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Andros!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes hands with a GUY who looks like the owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK shakes hands too. They cross the kitchen and go thro a bead curtain. Piped Greek music is playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smoke-filled private dining room. There is a poker game in Progress. FIVE MEN are playing, a DOZEN GIRLS are dott about watching. There is a trestle table laden with Greek food, from stews to salad, buffet-style. An improvised ba with ouzo, vodka and wine. It's help-yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are these guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly people in the casino  business. A few drug dealers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just girls. What are you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vodka. Straight. On the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good call. Help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK pours himself a vodka, scoops up some ice with his  hand from a bucket. Clouds of smoke envelop him. The nois is close to deafening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Bella come here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bitch? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poker game. A MAN with fair hair gets up, kisses a  GIRL whose dress is a bathing suit, puts his arm round he and they wander off. MATT is at the table. JACK is  replenishing his vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Jack, join us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Don't worry, I won't report you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't gamble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL appears behind JACK's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't gamble, but do you smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GIRL has a joint in her over-ringed hand. She is dres in purple Indian cotton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands him the  smoking joint) How about now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blows smoke in his face. JACK drains his vodka, pours himself another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK comes into the Gents, another smoke-filled room. Thr or four MEN are arguing over a drug deal, standing in fro of the urinal. One of them has an envelope full of cash,  another a packet of drugs. JACK goes to a lavatory stall, opens the door. In the sta the fair-haired MAN who was at Matt's table is sitting on the lavatory, his trousers round his ankles. The GIRL in  the bathing suit is sitting on his thighs, bobbing up and down. JACK sees a butterfly tattoo on her left cheek, the Queen of Spades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion. I'm on my way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK puts his arm on MATT's shoulder at the poker table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off. I need to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loosen up, Jack. If you don't,  this job'll get to you. The  pressure's too much, believe me,  it'll break you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The world breaks everyone, and  afterwards many are strong in the  broken places." Ernest Hemingway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK turns and leaves, helping himself to another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't he the one who shot himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK comes to the flat. He is drunk. He starts across the dark room. Suddenly the light comes on. JACK turns to see MARION, sitting in a chair in her night-dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where've you been? I've got to  give evidence in court at nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't play the cop with me, Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take that back! (furious) Fucking take that back. I'm not a  cop any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it back. You're not a cop  any more. You're a store detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fucking job's getting to you.  You haven't written a fucking word  since you started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have to swear all the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt) Well, that's my poor upbringing. I  didn't go to no private school. I  haven't got no class. I want to  live with a writer. Not a fucking  croupier. I don't even know what  the word means. Croupier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion, stop this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (near to tears) What do I mean to you? I want to  know. Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my conscience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you got a conscience of  your own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK has no answer. He goes into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The computer is still covered. JACK is standing at the  table dealing cards, practising. One card slips. He swear silently. He flexes his fingers, cracks his knuckle joint He looks at a skirt, legs, high heels, Passing above the  barred window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK emerges from the Underground, one of the CROWD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK goes into a large Department Store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARION is store-walking in the women's underwear departme It is Sale time. Baskets of tights and knickers on displa CUSTOMERS are rummaging. She is on the look-out for thiev She jumps as JACK places his hand on her hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? (looks round  nervously) You know the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about a drink on the way home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't finish till eight. Make it  nine and you're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on at nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's our life now, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK pauses in front of an airline office. There is a lar picture of Cape Town, and a special ticket offer. JANI comes out of the office. Her hair, tied back earlier in the casino, is now glamorously fluffed out. She sees  JACK. He doesn't see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking of going back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is startled. He doesn't recognise her for a moment.  Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) You know what? I'd like to buy you  a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's against the rules. Dealers  are forbidden to talk to punters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's stupid. What are the odds  of you being seen with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible to calculate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack knew that, in reality, all  odds are calculable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Art Deco bar. Expensive PEOPLE around. JANI and JACK  are installed on a sofa. A WAITER puts down two Martinis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raises her glass) To coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drinks) There's a casino in this hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not much of a gambler really.  I just like this bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why did you come to my casino?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at a loose end. A friend of  a friend gave me a courtesy  membership.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First visit to London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. I come every couple of  years. I always think I'm going to  stay. I'm from Cape Town originally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born in the Transkei, on the  Wild Coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's a coincidence. My father  used to gamble there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved the atmosphere. But it  destroyed my poor mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The debts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the lies. Gamblers are born  liars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) And superstitious too. It's like  witchcraft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Africa. There's an African  in all of us, isn't there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all came from Africa, supposedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe in astrology?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. But then, I'm a  Gemini and Geminis don't believe  in astrology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI laughs out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you don't strike me as a  typical croupier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI drinks. JACK notices her wedding ring. JANI catches  the look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not married. I wear it to keep  the flies off. (looks at her watch) I must go. Let me pay for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toss you for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't gamble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI nods, stands up, takes out a notepad and pen. She  looks round feigning conspiracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low voice) I know this is verboten, but if  you feel like a chat or maybe  dinner, give me a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scribbles her name and phone number on the pad, tears off the page, gives it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll understand if you don't. (smiles) But I hope you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. JACK watches her go, looks at the page she's  given him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of a mirror JACK trims his hair with nail scisso He is dressed in his croupier's uniform. He straightens  his bow tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't know why, but he'd started  to dress for the casino at home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK sits in the compartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... like a musician in his tuxedo,  going to the concert hall on public  transport...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ARAB at the end of the table kisses all his 50 chips and sets them out on the table. The wheel spins. JACK loo round at the PUNTERS. The ball bounces, falls on zero. Everybody loses. Many  groans. A MEDITERRANEAN-LOOKING MAN with a gold bracelet coughs. gob of phlegm from his mouth lands on a pile of chips tha JACK is raking away. A WOMAN in her mid-thirties is  appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Animal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind being more careful,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got 'flu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He coughs again, but into a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go back home. To the zoo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK clears the piles of chips to one side. He signals to a SUPERVISOR. The SUPERVISOR hurries over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gentleman accidentally coughed  onto these chips. I don't think it  would be hygienic to stack them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SUPERVISOR signals a WAITRESS over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes. These chips have to be  counted and put into the steamer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at JACK, grimaces, and takes the chips away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last PUNTERS are leaving. The overhead lights come on A CROUPIER is wheeling away a trolley with thousands of  chips. TWO MEN are covering the tables with shrouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS watches as JACK and MATT count the thousands of  pounds, putting them in piles. Behind them is a large ope safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't give you a lift back  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REYNOLDS places the notes in steel boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK, comes out. BELLA hurries after him, following him  round the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Jack. Do you need a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My car's in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe another time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take you up on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He straightens his hat and walks off. BELLA walks the oth way.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A MAN lurks in the shadows ahead of JACK. JACK doesn't se him. But as he comes past, the MAN steps out blocking JAC way. He is the Arabic-looking MAN JACK earlier caught  cheating at the casino with JANI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't recognise me? You had me  barred. You fucking little worm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You got yourself  barred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you, you shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAN reaches forward and grabs JACK'S tie. He yanks it with farce. JACK gasps. He rams his elbow into the MAN'S  chest. The MAN kicks JACK on the shins. JACK topples. The MAN  leaps at him. JACK, knees him in the groin. The fight is untidy and vicious. Both men collapse  struggling onto the pavement. A car appears, a Mini-Cooper. BELLA is driving. She sees  the fight. JACK'S nose is bleeding. The MAN kicks him in the back.  JACK yells with pain, gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm going to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He boots the MAN in the head. BELLA gets out of her car  and runs over to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAN is screening under JACK'S repeated blows. BELLA  pulls JACK away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack. Leave him! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK'S face is masked with blood and fury. BELLA is  frightened by JACK'S violence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. We don't want the cops  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she can get JACK into her car, he goes back to the MAN groaning on the floor. He stamps on the MAN's hand.  BELLA is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) He won't cheat again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BELLA pulls him away, bundles JACK into her car, gets in, drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water is running in the basin. BELLA puts JACK'S jacket o the lavatory seat. She starts to undo his tie. JACK wipes his blood-stained nose with a wet flannel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She undoes his shirt and takes it off. He winces. She was his torso, cleans him up. JACK looks at his shaking hands. BELLA takes him by the  hand, leads him into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits him on the bed. The room is lit with coloured  lamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse the mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK pulls her suddenly into his arms, pulls her onto the bed. She is startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK'S hands open her blouse. He reaches for her breast.  BELLA'S surprise becomes excitement. He kisses her hungri his hands rummaging in her clothes. She reaches for a sid zip in her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BELLA kicks off her shoes. There is a burst of passion  between them. For JACK, a continuation of the violence  with the MAN on the street. For BELLA, it's a sudden release. Her naked foot knocks  over the bedside lamp. JACK spreads BELLA on the bed. She tugs his trousers down He rips her black underwear away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. JACK is lying sprawled on the bed with BELLA. She  reaches across him and retrieves the fallen lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny, isn't it? If that guy  hadn't come up to you, you wouldn't  be here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK strokes her bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate cheats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All men are cheats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BELLA picks up a joint from the bedside and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spent two years on the game. I  don't mind telling you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't worry, I'm clean as a  whistle. I only did S & M. (she hands the joint  to JACK,) No blow jobs. No screwing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you quit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inhales) I can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you? I'm happy being a dealer.  At least the punters keep their  hands to themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called the casino a cesspit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it is. But I know where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK hands the joint back to BELLA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been watching you work. You're  the best in the place. But you  know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I despise the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, we all say that. But if we  hate it, why do we do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack wanted to say we do it for  the money. But that wasn't really  true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BELLA leans over JACK and begins gently to massage his  flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you really want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the joint in an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indian rope-trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, now I'm pumping you. I'm  sorry. It's none of my business.   It's just that you're not like the  others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like Matt, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's a real shit. Don't get  friendly with him. I'm sure he's  got his hand in the till. You know  what he said to me once? "I want  to fuck the whole world over. That's  my mission." The shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BELLA touches a bruise on JACK'S body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses the bruised skin, pulls him to her. BELLA simp wants to be held.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack could hear Matt saying it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is at his desk typing intently. There is a pile of  new pages in the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I want to fuck the whole world  over. It's my mission."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARION passes in the foreground. She kisses him on the  back of his head and leaves. JACK'S fingers move across  the keyboard, dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last he had found what he'd  been looking for. A clear and simple  theme. And a hero to act it out.  Little Matt... (Pause) ...Chapter One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATT is shaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look like shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is scrubbing his nails at a basin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rough day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rough life, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG WOMAN appears in the mirror behind the two MEN.  Her name is PAT. She is dressed like BELLA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Pat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATT and JACK say 'Hello'. MATT appraises PAT'S appearanc winks approval at JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Matt) What happened to Bella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is mystified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is dealing to MR TCHAI and three OTHER MEN. One chai at the table is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to Bella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was re-assigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK shows 13. He turns over his third card, a King. The  bank busts. JACK pays out. JANI sits down in the vacant chair. JACK conceals his  surprise, a hint of nervousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (formally) Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI nods impassively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack knew this was no coincidence.  Why had she come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MEN look at the glamorous woman. MR TCHAI doesn't  register her presence. He is as inscrutable as his BODYGU who hands him an envelope. JANI takes out money from her  purse. JACK counts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thousand even. In fifties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK slots the money down, counts out 20 50 chips. JACK deals. Bets are placed. 100 from JANI. The cards turn. MR TCHAI splits two aces. JANI has a 6 and 7. MR TCHAI recei two los and wins big. JANI gets a 10 and busts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wondered if she believed he  would bring her luck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI'S face is impassive. She receives her cards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI busts again. JACK sweeps away the chips, the cards.  JANI reaches into her bag, takes out another thousand  pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fifties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MEN at the table look at JANI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or did she think he would help her  win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI loses again. She is down to 4 chips. She looks up at JACK. Their eyes meet, hers desperate, his helpless. MR  TCHAI picks up on the look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew how to fix it for her. His  father had taught him the trick.  Switch the sequence. Bust the bank.  The casino wouldn't spot it. But  Jack was wary of the punters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK glances at the MEN at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could see Mr Tchai was counting.  He couldn't risk it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANI places her last bet, glances at the mountain of chip in front of MR TCHAI. JACK catches her look. He deals.  JANI reaches for her next card. JACK observes her left  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He noticed she wasn't wearing her  ring. Why not? Odds on she'd sold  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK plays out the hand. JANI loses. She immediately gets up. She is crushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, she said. For what,  Jack thought. Jani de Villiers  knew the odds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TCHAI looks at JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is sitting on the bed fully clothed. He is carefully sewing a button on his croupier's jacket. Through the ope bedroom door MARION can be seen sitting on the sofa, legs tucked under her, reading the new typescript. The phone rings. In the bedroom JACK picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK SR. is in a public phone. Coloured lanterns hang rou in the night. Distant laughter.
